metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: XML DOM - Navigating Nodes
Nodes can be navigated using node relationships.
content.html: Nodes can be navigated using node relationships.

content.text: Navigating DOM Nodes
Accessing nodes in the node tree via the relationship between nodes, is often called "navigating nodes".
content.html: Accessing nodes in the node tree via the relationship between nodes, is often called "navigating nodes".

content.text: In the XML DOM, node relationships are defined as properties to the nodes:
content.html: In the XML DOM, node relationships are defined as properties to the nodes:

content.text: The following image illustrates a part of the node tree and the relationship between nodes in books.xml :
content.html: The following image illustrates a part of the node tree and the relationship between nodes in books.xml:

content.text: DOM - Parent Node
All nodes have exactly one parent node. The following code navigates to the parent node of <book>:
content.html: All nodes have exactly one parent node. The following code navigates to the parent node of <book>:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction(xml) {    var xmlDoc = xml.responseXML;    var x = xmlDoc.getElementsByTagName("book")[0];    
    document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = x.parentNode.nodeName;}

content.code:
function myFunction(xml) { var xmlDoc = xml.responseXML;    var x = xmlDoc.getElementsByTagName("book")[0];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = x.parentNode.nodeName;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction(xml) { var xmlDoc = xml.responseXML;    var x = xmlDoc.getElementsByTagName("book")[0];    
    document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = x.parentNode.nodeName;}

content.code_html:
function myFunction(xml) {
var xmlDoc = xml.responseXML;
    var x = xmlDoc.getElementsByTagName("book")[0];
    document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = x.parentNode.nodeName;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction(xml) {    var xmlDoc = xml.responseXML;    var x = xmlDoc.getElementsByTagName("book")[0];    
    document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = x.parentNode.nodeName;}

content.text: Example explained:
Avoid Empty Text Nodes
Some browsers might treat empty white-spaces or new lines as text nodes. This causes a problem when using the properties: firstChild, lastChild, nextSibling, previousSibling.
content.html: Some browsers might treat empty white-spaces or new lines as text nodes. This causes a problem when using the properties: firstChild, lastChild, nextSibling, previousSibling.

content.text: To avoid navigating to empty text nodes (spaces and new-line characters between element nodes), we use a function that checks the node type:
content.html: To avoid navigating to empty text nodes (spaces and new-line characters between element nodes), we use a function that checks the node type:

content.code_html:
function get_nextSibling(n) {
    var y = n.nextSibling;
    while (y.nodeType != 1) {
        y = y.nextSibling;
    }
    return y;
}

content.text: The function above allows you to use get_nextSibling( node ) instead of the property node .nextSibling.
content.html: The function above allows you to use get_nextSibling(node) instead of the property node.nextSibling.

content.text: Code explained:
Element nodes are type 1. If the sibling node is not an element node, it moves to the next nodes until an element node is found.
content.html: Element nodes are type 1. If the sibling node is not an element node, it moves to the next nodes until an element node is found.

content.text: Get the First Child Element
The following code displays the first element node of the first <book>:
content.html: The following code displays the first element node of the first <book>:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
//check if 
 the first node is an element node

syntax_highlighting.text:
//check if 
 the first node is an element node

content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>

<p id="demo"></p>

<script>
var xhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
xhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
    if (this.readyState == 4 && this.status == 200) {
        myFunction(this);
    }
};
xhttp.open("GET", "books.xml", true);
xhttp.send();

function myFunction(xml) {
    var xmlDoc = xml.responseXML;
    var x = get_firstChild(xmlDoc.getElementsByTagName("book")[0]);
    document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = x.nodeName;
}

//check if the first node is an element node
function get_firstChild(n) {
    var y = n.firstChild;
    while (y.nodeType != 1) {
        y = y.nextSibling;
    }
    return y;
}
</script>

</body>
</html>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
//check if 
 the first node is an element node

content.text: Example explained:
More Examples
lastChild() Use the lastChild() method and a custom function to get the last child node of a node.
content.html:
lastChild()
Use the lastChild() method and a custom function to get the last child node of a node.

content.text: nextSibling() Use the nextSibling() method and a custom function to get the next sibling node of a node.
content.html:
nextSibling()
Use the nextSibling() method and a custom function to get the next sibling node of a node.

content.text: previousSibling() Use the previousSibling() method and a custom function to get the previous sibling node of a node.
content.html:
previousSibling()
Use the previousSibling() method and a custom function to get the previous sibling node of a node.
